Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Building Forest Management into Earth System Modeling: Scaling from Stand to Continent
Award.AbstractNarration:
Although there are many theories that explain how forests function at the stand level, there is a lack of understanding of how these theories scale to larger areas subject to different disturbances, such as hurricanes or harvests, which cause temporary change in environmental conditions. Management of forest resources has been guided by ecological theories that simplify disturbance, management, and climate impacts on forests, but feedbacks from management are seldom considered to influence function. This observation leads to an important question: How does knowledge from studies of areas measured in meters or kilometers apply to much more heterogeneous regional areas, within which human activities are becoming the most significant determinants of functional responses to disturbances? This proposed research aims to develop a framework for building forest management into Earth system modeling to test whether stand-level ecological theories hold in larger areas across different regions of the continental US. The goal is to determine how variations in forest management, climate, and disturbance impact forest ecosystems, and quantify the relative importance of forest management, climate, and disturbance as drivers of ecosystem structure and function at stand to continental scales. Initial spatial data on land ownership and use, forest management, disturbances, climate, and vegetation characteristics will be obtained for two regions of the US with significant management activity: the Southeast and Pacific Northwest. The project will map management, disturbances, and environmental characteristics overlain on forest types. An ecosystem model will be modified and parameterized to generate estimates of carbon, water, and forest structure characteristics under various management and climate scenarios in order to investigate if the macrosystem behaves similarly or as the aggregate of the mosaic of different stages of succession, management, disturbance, and climate change scenarios.

This continental-scale analysis of management, disturbance, and climatic effects on forest structure and function will lead ecologists and forest resource managers towards improved stewardship of forest resources. This project will make substantive contributions in developing methods for appropriate scale determination and management mapping, and demonstrate how management methods affect forest ecology. Moreover, new frameworks and improvements will be made to improve existing ecosystem models. This project will improve ecological theory of succession to better inform forest management, which will help in evaluating forest feedbacks on climatic patterns. Research data products will made available to forest managers via outreach activities, including field-based workshops. The greatest significance of this project will be to design new research approaches and contribute to training a new generation of scientists through graduate research and cross-disciplinary post-doctoral training with multi-institution lab rotations. The project will improve our understanding of the interactions of forest management at larger scales with disturbance regimes and climate change influences, as well as how management activities might mitigate some of those influences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Management of forest resources for harvest, recreation, and ecosystem management involves close partnerships among multiple public and private groups and individuals. However, most management practices to improve forest ecosystem services have been guided by ecological theories that oversimplify the effects of disturbance, management, and environmental impacts on forests. Further, most of these simplified theories were developed at the scale of small forest study plots, while these effects tend to occur over multiple spatial and temporal scales. Therefore, this project asked: How do the theories of forest function that we know from studies of areas measured in meters to kilometers apply to much more heterogeneous areas measured in thousands of kilometers, within which human activities may become the most significant determinants of functional responses to disturbances? To answer this, we developed a framework for building forest management into Earth system modeling, and conducted analyses to test whether stand-level ecological theories hold in larger areas. Results inform improved forest management and policy at regional and national scales, and prediction of the impact of management on forest ecology in a changing environment.

We focused our analysis on two contrasting regions that also have significant forested areas: the southeastern US (SEUS) and the Pacific Northwest (PNW). We determined that at larger spatial scales, we can define and successfully map forest management into four categories: production forestry, ecological forestry, wilderness/preservation, and passive forestry. In each region, our multidisciplinary team worked to determine scales of analysis, map forest management types and estimate the uncertainty of the mapping, review stand-level effects of management on ecosystem processes, build management into a state-of-the-art dynamic vegetation and biogeochemical simulation model, and assess model predictions against field data sets at multiple scales.

This collaborative project involved a diverse group of scientists and students across seven Institutions, with expertise in mapping, modeling, and forest ecology. The mapping group contributed expertise in satellite remote sensing, algorithm development for mapping forest management, and conducting the actual mapping and uncertainty analysis. This expertise was complemented by expertise in forest ecology and modeling, which enabled the production of mapped forest management type data products derived from time series analysis of satellite remote sensing imagery and other spatial data.  The modeling group implemented a forest management module in an ecosystem demography model, using prototype data from across our study region and parameterized utilizing publicly available datasets and expertise from the forest ecology group.

Several major advances were required for mapping forest management, a land use that is not usually determinable with satellite imagery: 1) we used methods of analysis that yielded multiple time series variables that differed among the four forest management types, 2) we combined many different kinds of spatial data such as land ownership, forest type and cover, road networks, historic disturbances, and high temporal resolution satellite imagery to generate other variables that differentiate forest management types, 3) we conducted an accurate classification of forest management types in forested areas of both the SEUS and PNW, and 4) we devised a way to calculate classification uncertainty at the 10km region within which the ecosystem modeling is done.

As part of a collaborative project, the forest ecology group contributed expertise in ecosystem and climate processes, and meteorological and climate data sources. This enabled the modeling group to select appropriate prototype sites and critically evaluate results. Three major advances were required for the modeling: 1) incorporating spatially-implicit modeling of management, fire and pest disturbances, 2) providing for generalized modeling of forest insects and pathogens, and 3) developing a forest management functional type framework. Simulations at test sites showed a strong impact of forest management over other sources of change across regions. Moreover, these analyses provided the basis for exploration of the socioecological theory of forest macrosystem ecology, especially as it pertains to forest management.

Advances were disseminated at national conferences, and documented in peer-reviewed publications and data products prepared for serving to forest managers and scientists. The project also contributed to educating a new generation of scientists through graduate research and cross-disciplinary post-doctoral training.
